case_vignette: A 20-year-old man presents with a painless neck mass that has gradually increased in size. The mass is anteromedial to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle and has been present for 3 years. The mass increased in size and became more tender following an upper respiratory infection. An ultrasound of the neck identifies a single, round cystic mass with uniform, low echogenicity, and no internal septations. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck shows a homogeneous mass with low attenuation centrally and with smooth rim enhancement.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painless bump on my neck that has slowly gotten bigger over the last 3 years.
How old are you?
I'm 20 years old.
Are you male or female?
I am male.
Have you observed any other symptoms like night sweats, fever, or weight loss?
No, I haven't experienced any of those symptoms.
Do you have any difficulty breathing or swallowing?
No, I don't have any difficulty breathing or swallowing.
Have you had any previous medical issues or surgeries?
No, I haven't had any previous medical issues or surgeries.
Is there any family history of cancer or benign tumors?
I don't know of any family history of cancer or benign tumors.
Do you have any history of infections or illnesses that could have caused lymph node swelling?
The bump on my neck got more tender and bigger after I had an upper respiratory infection.
Has the bump on your neck ever decreased in size after the respiratory infection resolved?
No, the bump has not decreased in size after the respiratory infection resolved.
Have you taken any medications or treatments for the bump on your neck?
No, I haven't taken any medications or treatments for the bump on my neck.
Final Diagnosis: Enlarging, persistent lymphadenopathy, possibly benign lymphadenopathy or lymphoproliferative disorder. Further evaluation with imaging and biopsy is recommended.
